title: Simple circuits - 4 switches to light 1 of 3 bulbs

content.description: In the circuit shown in the figure, switches <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="S sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="S sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> are used to control light bulbs <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>. Which of the following switch settings results in only one of the three bulbs having charge flow through it and lighting up?
content.question: <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math><math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math><math alttext="S sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>S</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math><math alttext="S sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math>AClosedOpenOpenClosedBClosedClosedOpenClosedCOpenClosedOpenClosedDOpenOpenClosedOpen

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
